parent_formation: Allied Forces North Africa (18th Army Group)

commander.name: Lieutenant-General Kenneth Arthur Noel Anderson
commander.previous_service: Commanded II Corps (UK) and Eastern Command before selection to command First Army for Operation Torch (November 1942). Led Allied forces in Tunisia Campaign from November 1942 through final Axis surrender 13 May 1943. Coordinated British, American, and French forces under difficult coalition conditions. Known for defensive skill during Operation Ochsenkopf (German counterattack February-March 1943) and methodical preparation for final Tunisia offensive (Operations Vulcan and Strike, April-May 1943). Oversaw largest British-led coalition army since World War I. First Army captured Tunis (7 May) and accepted Axis surrender (13 May, 240,000+ POWs). Anderson removed from command after Tunisia victory, replaced by Alexander. Received KCB but perceived as insufficiently aggressive compared to Montgomery's Eighth Army.
commander.note: Anderson commanded through entire Tunisia Campaign (November 1942 - May 1943) but was replaced after victory, not selected for Sicily invasion command. Controversial figure - coalition management skills vs. perceived lack of offensive drive.

command.headquarters_location: Constantine, Algeria (rear headquarters) with advanced command posts in northern Tunisia (Tebourba-Medjez el Bab sector during final offensive April-May 1943). Post-13 May: Tunis area for occupation and reorganization.

1.note: Standard British/Commonwealth rifle across all First Army divisions

2.note: Section-level automatic weapon, all British infantry

Churchill Mk III/IV Infantry Tank.note: 4th Infantry Division organic tank brigade (21st Army Tank Brigade). Churchill infantry tanks supported 4th Division operations. Unique mixed division structure within V Corps.

tanks.note: V Corps was primarily infantry corps (1st, 4th, 78th Infantry Divisions). Only tank component was 4th Division's organic 21st Army Tank Brigade (165 Churchill infantry tanks). 25th Tank Brigade also attached to V Corps during April operations but specific tank counts not aggregated here to avoid double-counting with division extractions.

Universal Carrier.role: Infantry support, mortar carriers (6th Armoured Division)

M3 Half-Track.role: Motorized infantry transport (6th Armoured Division Lend-Lease)

halftracks.note: British divisions did not use halftracks extensively. Universal Carriers fulfilled similar role.

CMP (Canadian Military Pattern) trucks.role: Canadian-built trucks, widely used in First Army

Specialized vehicles (water, fuel, works.role: Support vehicles including water bowsers, fuel bowsers, recovery

Recovery tractors and engineering equipm.role: Scammell Pioneer recovery, engineering bridging equipment

Fuel bowsers.role: Fuel distribution from ports to forward units

Ordnance QF 25-pounder Mk II.note: Divisional artillery: V Corps (240 guns from 1st, 4th, 78th Divisions), IX Corps armoured divisions (48 guns each from 1st and 6th Armoured = 96), 46th Division (96), other divisions (144). First Army 25-pdrs participated in massive bombardments during Operations Vulcan and Strike.

Ordnance QF 5.5-inch Gun-Howitzer.note: Corps medium artillery regiments (V Corps: 48 guns, IX Corps estimated: 24 guns). Long-range counter-battery and interdiction fires.

Ordnance QF 6-pounder (57mm).note: Divisional anti-tank regiments across all infantry divisions. Primary British AT gun 1943.

Ordnance QF 17-pounder.note: Divisional and corps AT assets. High-velocity AT gun capable against Tiger tanks. Increased allocation during 1943. V Corps (48), IX Corps (24), 46th Division (10), other units (16).

Corps Anti-Tank Reserve.note: Additional corps-level AT assets for mobile reserve.

Bofors 40mm.note: Corps and divisional light AA assets. V Corps (54), IX Corps (30), 46th Division (24 estimated).

Oerlikon/Polsten 20mm.note: Supplementary AA defense, V Corps and division HQs.

3-inch Mortar.note: Infantry battalion mortars across all divisions. Standard 12 mortars per battalion.

supply_logistics.supply_status: ADEQUATE TO EXCELLENT - First Army supply status improved dramatically Q2 1943 compared to difficult winter/early spring conditions. April (Operations Vulcan period): Supply lines from Algerian ports (Algiers, Bone) to northern Tunisia front (300-400km) maintained adequately. Heavy ammunition expenditure during final offensive required careful logistics management but stockpiles adequate. May 1-13 (Operation Strike): Excellent supply buildup enabled massive artillery bombardments and sustained offensive operations. Post-13 May (Axis surrender): Supply situation excellent with captured Tunis and Bizerte ports available. First Army controlled both major Tunisian ports, enabling rapid buildup for Sicily invasion preparations. June: Reconstitution period with excellent port access. Coalition logistics challenge coordinating British, American, and French supply chains under single First Army headquarters. Extended supply lines from Algerian ports to Tunisia front (300-400km) strained transport capacity during April offensive but manageable. Captured Axis supply dumps after 13 May provided bonus material.
notes: April: Operation Vulcan preliminary attacks - heavy logistics demand from multiple corps
May 1-13: Operations Vulcan/Strike final offensive - massive ammunition consumption (600+ gun bombardments)
Notable: V Corps night 5-6 May 16,000 artillery shells fired in two hours (single division sector)
13 May: Tunisia Campaign ends with complete Axis surrender (240,000+ POWs)
Post-May 13: Excellent supply situation, Tunis/Bizerte ports captured and operational
June: Reconstitution period, divisions prepared for Sicily invasion (some First Army divisions transferred to Eighth Army)
Coalition logistics: British base from Algiers, American supplies through Oran, French forces supplied through both
Extended supply lines (300-400km from ports) manageable but strained during April offensive
Captured Axis supply dumps provided bonus fuel, ammunition, and equipment after 13 May

weather_environment.terrain_type: Northern Tunisia: Tebourba-Medjez el Bab-Tunis sector. Medjerda Valley (relatively flat agricultural land with river) providing main axis of advance, surrounded by rugged hills and djebels (steep heights). Limited road network channeling movement. Defensive terrain favoring Axis defenders until final Allied offensive. Mountain terrain requiring infantry-led assaults. Coastal plains near Tunis and Bizerte. Agricultural land providing some cover but restricting vehicle movement. Rocky hills requiring infantry assaults with armor support limited to valleys. First Army operations concentrated in northern Tunisia hill country contrasting with Eighth Army's southern desert approaches.
weather_environment.seasonal_impact: Spring conditions transitioning to early summer. April saw improving weather after difficult winter rains, enabling Allied offensive operations (Operation Vulcan, 22 April start). May brought increasingly hot and dry conditions - excellent for operations but dust became significant factor. Good flying weather throughout April-May enabled Allied air superiority over Tunisia critical for ground operations success. June full summer heat established. Campaign ended 13 May 1943 before summer extremes. Northern Tunisia terrain and climate less harsh than Western Desert but restrictive terrain channeled operations.
environmental_challenges: Hilly terrain channeling movement into predictable valleys - Axis defensive advantage
Limited road network - few all-weather routes, easily blocked by defenders
Medjerda Valley key axis of advance but well-defended German positions
Djebel heights required infantry assaults - armor support limited to valleys
Dust from vehicle movement and artillery fire affecting visibility
Heat stress increasing through May (peak combat operations)
Water requirements significant for coalition army (British, American, French forces)
Agricultural areas sometimes providing cover, sometimes obstacle to movement
Contrast with Eighth Army's desert expertise - First Army adapted to mountain/hill warfare
Coalition coordination challenges across varied national logistics and operational methods

subordinate_units.note: V Corps main First Army formation April-May 1943. Three infantry divisions (1st, 4th, 78th) plus attached armor. Executed northern Tunisia breakthrough operations April-May. Participated in Operations Vulcan and Strike. 4th Division unique mixed division structure with organic 21st Army Tank Brigade (165 Churchill tanks).

subordinate_units.commander: Lieutenant-General John Crocker (until injured late April), then Lieutenant-General Brian Horrocks
subordinate_units.note: IX Corps arrived Tunisia March 1943. Commanded 1st and 6th Armoured Divisions plus attached infantry. Crocker wounded in PIAT training accident late April, replaced by Horrocks for final offensive (Operation Strike, 5-13 May). IX Corps armoured spearhead broke through Medjez-el-Bab gap enabling dash to Tunis (captured 7 May). Coalition forces: US 34th Infantry Division attached early operations. NOT EXTRACTED YET - estimated strength and composition.

46th Division First Army operations Q2 1943. Participated Operation Vulcan (April), army reserve late April-early May, final offensive operations toward Tunis (May). Three infantry brigades. Supported by attached armor during operations.

US II Corps under First Army operational control April-early May 1943. Bradley replaced Patton 15 April. II Corps operated southern sector Tunisia offensive. Three divisions (1st Infantry 'Big Red One', 1st Armored, 9th Infantry) plus attachments. II Corps transferred back to US Fifth Army command after Tunisia victory for Sicily invasion preparation. Coalition forces under Anderson's First Army headquarters.

French XIX Corps under First Army operational control Q2 1943. Composed Free French and French North African divisions. Operated central Tunisia sector during final offensive. Coalition forces under Anderson's coordination. French formations critical for manpower and local knowledge. NOT EXTRACTED (French units outside current project scope) - estimated strength.

Army-level support: Royal Engineers (bridging, mine clearance), Royal Signals (communications network), RASC (logistics convoys), RAOC (ordnance depots), RAMC (field hospitals), Provost (military police). Essential for maintaining coalition army in extended offensive operations April-May 1943. Coordinated British, American, and French logistics and communications.

tactical_doctrine.role: British First Army primary Allied formation executing final Tunisia offensive (Operations Vulcan and Strike, April-May 1943). Coalition army (British, American, French) under Lieutenant-General Kenneth Anderson operating northern Tunisia sector. Mission: Coordinate multi-national offensive to capture Tunis and Bizerte, envelop Axis forces, and force unconditional surrender ending North Africa campaign. First Army executed coordinated corps-level attacks with massive artillery support, combined arms operations, and methodical reduction of German/Italian defensive positions in restrictive hill terrain. Final offensive 5-13 May 1943 resulted in British entry to Tunis (7 May), US capture of Bizerte, and complete Axis surrender (13 May, 240,000+ POWs). First Army dissolved after Tunisia victory with divisions transferred to Eighth Army for Sicily invasion or withdrawn for rest/refit.
special_capabilities: Coalition army command - coordinating British, American, and French forces under single headquarters
Multi-corps operations - V Corps (infantry), IX Corps (armoured), US II Corps, French XIX Corps
Massive artillery fires - 600+ guns available for major attacks across First Army front
Combined arms expertise - infantry, armour, artillery coordination in restrictive terrain
Mountain/hill warfare adapted from desert warfare - First Army specialized in Tunisia terrain
Logistics coordination - integrating British, American, and French supply chains
Set-piece attack planning - methodical operations with overwhelming firepower
Urban warfare capabilities - Tunis and Bizerte capture operations
tactical_innovations: Coalition army command - Anderson managed British, American, and French formations under single operational headquarters
Massive multi-corps artillery concentrations - 600+ gun bombardments coordinated across First Army front
Armoured breakthrough exploitation - IX Corps armoured divisions broke through for Tunis dash (7 May)
Night operations with rolling barrages - multiple corps executing simultaneous night attacks
Methodical reduction of defensive positions through overwhelming firepower vs. maneuver
Coalition logistics coordination - British, American, and French supply systems integrated under First Army
Corps-level fire support coordination enabling divisional and brigade assaults
known_issues: Coalition friction - British, American, and French operational methods differed
Anderson's leadership style - perceived as insufficiently aggressive compared to Montgomery
Extended supply lines from Algerian ports (300-400km) strained logistics during April offensive
Terrain heavily favored defenders - channelized Allied movement into predictable valleys
Mixed experience levels - veteran divisions alongside fresh formations learning combat
US II Corps Kasserine Pass lessons (February 1943) required rebuilding American confidence
French forces equipment shortages - legacy of 1940 defeat and Vichy period
Coordination challenges between corps operating in restrictive terrain
Anderson removed from command after Tunisia victory - not selected for Sicily invasion command (controversial decision)
tactical_doctrine.terrain_adaptations: First Army adapted British doctrine for northern Tunisia mountain/hill terrain: infantry-led assaults to seize djebels (heights), artillery massed fires supporting attacks, armour in direct fire support in valleys (terrain too restrictive for mobile operations like Western Desert), extensive engineer support for road maintenance and obstacle clearance, set-piece attacks with careful planning rather than mobile warfare, methodical operations overwhelming Axis defenders through firepower superiority rather than maneuver. Contrast with Eighth Army's desert mobile warfare doctrine - First Army specialized in mountain warfare similar to Italian campaign later 1943-1945.

scenario_suitability: Operation Vulcan (22 April - 1 May 1943) - First Army offensive northern Tunisia
Operation Strike (5-13 May 1943) - Final Tunisia offensive with massive artillery support and armoured breakthrough
Tunis capture (7 May 1943) - British IX Corps armoured dash to capital
Bizerte capture (7 May 1943) - US II Corps capture of port
Coalition army command scenarios - coordinating British, American, and French forces
Multi-corps offensive operations with 4-5 corps under single army headquarters
Set-piece attacks with overwhelming firepower in restrictive mountain terrain
Combined infantry-armour operations - V Corps infantry breakthrough enabling IX Corps armoured exploitation
British First Army vs. Afrika Korps/Italian forces - Tunisia endgame
Mountain/hill warfare scenarios contrasting with desert warfare
Army-level artillery coordination and massed fires (600+ guns)
Coalition friction scenarios - managing multi-national force operational differences
wargaming_data.experience_level: Mixed - Elite veteran divisions (78th Division), veteran divisions (1st Division), regular fresh divisions (4th Division from UK), mixed American divisions (post-Kasserine rebuilding), French divisions (variable experience)
special_rules: Anderson Coalition Command: First Army benefits from experienced coalition commander (+1 coordination for multi-national operations, -1 for perceived lack of offensive drive vs. Montgomery)
Artillery Dominance: British massed fires doctrine (+2 to artillery effectiveness when coordinating army-level fires, 600+ guns available)
Mixed Experience: 78th Division elite veteran (+1 all rolls), 1st Division veteran, 4th Division regular (fresh from UK), US divisions variable (post-Kasserine recovery), French divisions variable
Terrain Restrictions: Armour movement severely limited in hill country (-2 mobility for tanks off-road, valleys only)
Coalition Army: First Army includes British, American, and French forces (coordination challenges -1 first turn each battle, +1 after coordination established)
Set-Piece Attacks: First Army excels at prepared attacks (+1 planning bonus for attacks with 24+ hours preparation)
Army Artillery Reserve: May mass fires from 72x 5.5-inch medium guns plus 576x 25-pounders for breakthrough operations
IX Corps Armoured Breakthrough: IX Corps (1st and 6th Armoured Divisions) may execute exploitation after infantry breakthrough (+2 breakthrough exploitation, -1 in restrictive terrain)
Axis Surrender: Historical scenario ends 13 May 1943 with Axis surrender (240,000+ POWs, largest surrender since Stalingrad)
historical_engagements: Operation Torch landings (8 November 1942) - First Army formation and Algeria landings
Race for Tunis (November-December 1942) - First Army advance to Tunisia frontier (failed to capture Tunis before Axis reinforced)
Winter stalemate (December 1942-March 1943) - Difficult winter conditions and Axis counterattacks
Operation Ochsenkopf (26 February - 2 March 1943) - German counterattack vs. V Corps (repulsed)
Operation Vulcan preliminary attacks (22-28 April 1943) - First Army offensive northern Tunisia sector
Operation Strike (5-13 May 1943) - Final offensive, massive bombardments, armoured breakthrough
Tunis capture (7 May 1943) - IX Corps armoured dash to capital (7th Armoured Division entered Tunis)
Bizerte capture (7 May 1943) - US II Corps capture of port
Axis surrender Tunisia (13 May 1943) - 240,000+ German and Italian POWs, campaign ends (largest Allied victory to date)

Post-13 May composition unclear - First Army dissolved/reorganized after Tunisia victory

chief_of_staff.reason: First Army Chief of Staff name not documented in available web sources for Q2 1943. Major-General rank confirmed (standard for army COS). Would require UK National Archives War Diaries for identification. Minor impact on wargaming scenarios.
sources_checked: WebSearch - Kenneth Anderson First Army command
chief_of_staff.mitigation: Army commander (Anderson) well-documented. Corps commanders identified (Allfrey, Crocker/Horrocks, Bradley). Staff strength estimated from British army establishment.

ix_corps_not_extracted.reason: IX Corps (Crocker/Horrocks) confirmed present April-May 1943 but NOT YET EXTRACTED in project. IX Corps commanded 1st and 6th Armoured Divisions plus attached infantry (US 34th, 4th Indian, 4th Infantry at various times). Strength and equipment estimated from subordinate divisions and standard British corps establishments. IX Corps critical for armoured breakthrough Operation Strike (5-13 May).
sources_checked: WebSearch - British First Army order of battle 20 April 1943
ix_corps_not_extracted.mitigation: Subordinate divisions provide 80%+ of corps combat power. IX Corps estimated at 45,000 personnel, 478 tanks (1st and 6th Armoured Divisions plus attachments). Operational role well-documented (armoured breakthrough, Tunis capture 7 May).

french_xix_corps.reason: French XIX Corps under First Army operational control Q2 1943 but OUTSIDE PROJECT SCOPE (French units not being extracted). Commanded by General Alphonse Juin. Composed Free French and French North African divisions. Critical for central Tunisia sector operations. Strength estimated at 42,000 personnel, 85 tanks.
sources_checked: WebSearch - First Army order of battle April 1943
Project scope documentation (French units excluded from current phase)
french_xix_corps.mitigation: French forces under First Army operational control documented. Exact composition outside project scope. Estimate provides operational context for First Army coalition command role.

first_army_dissolution.reason: First Army composition after 13 May Axis surrender unclear. Anderson removed from command after Tunisia victory (June 1943). Many divisions transferred to Eighth Army for Sicily invasion (July 1943). First Army headquarters likely reorganized or dissolved. This extraction represents April-May 1943 operational composition (peak combat operations period).
sources_checked: WebSearch - British First Army after Tunisia victory
WebSearch - Kenneth Anderson removal from command
Sicily invasion order of battle (divisions transferred)
first_army_dissolution.mitigation: Q2 1943 represents final First Army operations period (April-May combat, June reconstitution). Historical record clear for combat operations. Post-victory reorganization less critical for wargaming scenarios focused on Tunisia Campaign finale.

validation.methodology: Bottom-up aggregation from subordinate corps where available (V Corps, US II Corps). IX Corps estimated from subordinate divisions and standard establishments. French XIX Corps estimated (outside project scope). Personnel: V Corps (53,636) + IX Corps (45,000 estimated) + 46th Division (17,450) + US II Corps (59,749 - counted separately as American) + French XIX Corps (42,000 estimated) + First Army HQ and troops (8,800) = 148,650 British personnel (excluding US II Corps for British totals). Equipment: Aggregated from subordinate formations with estimates for IX Corps and French forces. Tactical doctrine based on Operations Vulcan and Strike historical accounts. Supply status based on subordinate corps files and First Army logistics reports. First Army represented at peak operational strength April-May 1943 (coalition army executing final Tunisia offensive).

aggregation_notes: Aggregated from 3 subordinate units. Previous totals: 219736 personnel, 165 tanks.
